titleStmt.title: The gentlewoman's delight in cookery containing the newest art of dressing all sorts of flesh, fowl, or fish, either roasted, boiled, baked, stewed, fryed, broyled, hasht or frigaced. Together with the true way of raising paste, and making pyes, pasties, tarts, cakes, custards, &c. Also how to make all sorts of broths, caudles, syrups, jellies; and the exact way of making divers sorts of pickles, &c. Likewise directions for garnishing, serving up, and setting out a table; ... To which is added, the art of preserving, conserving, and candying all sorts of fruits, flowers, buds, roots, herbs, &c. With a most excellent receipt for making beautifying water to clear the face, neck, hands, & whiten the skin. Very beneficial for all young gentlewomen and servant-maids. Licensed according to order.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Gentlewoman's Delight IN COOKERY.

figure.figDesc: woodcut of kitchen and dinner scenes

div.p: Licen≈øed according to Order.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ NDON, Printed for J. Back, at the Black
THE Gentlewoman's Delight IN Cookery: CONTAINING The newe≈øt Art of Dre≈ø≈øing all ≈øorts of Fle≈øh, Fowl, or Fi≈øh, either Roa≈øted, Boiled, Baked, Stewed, Fryed, Broyled, Ha≈øht or Frigaced.
TOGETHER With the true way of Rai≈øing Pa≈øte, and making Pyes, Pa≈øties, Tarts, Cakes; Cu≈øtards, &c.
Al≈øo how to make all ≈øorts of Broths, Caudles, Syrups, Jellies; and the exact way of making divers ≈øorts of Pickles, &c.

LIKEWISE Directions for Garni≈øhing, Serving up, and Setting out a Table; with Rules for Carving and Pre≈øenting the be≈øt and mo≈øt acceptable pieces, after the mo≈øt modi≈øh way, u≈øed either in England or France.

To which is Added, The Art of Pre≈øerving, Con≈øerving, and Candying all ≈øorts of Fruits, Flowers, Buds, Roots, Herbs, &c. With a mo≈øt excellent Receipt for making a Beautfying Water to clear the Face, Neck, Hands, & whiten the Skin.
Very Beneficial for all young Gentlewomen and Servant-Maids.
Licen≈øed according to Order.
Printed for J. Back‚ñ™ on London-Bridge

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER
div.p: SEeing Things of this Nature are n ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ held plea≈øant but profitable, by inabling the Ingenious Reader, to put them i ‚Ä¢ practice, I conceived it not ami≈øs to Collect ≈øuch Curio≈øities as are not vulgarly known; the which, if rightly ob≈øerve ‚Ä¢ in their re≈øpective Places and Offices mu≈øt, in all probability, Redound to th ‚Ä¢ Advantage and Accompl√Ø≈øhment of eithe ‚Ä¢ Sex. Wherefore not longer to detain yo ‚Ä¢ with a Preface, I proceed to what is nonmaterial. And fir≈øt of Cookery, ≈ø ‚Ä¢ nece≈ø≈øary to be known, in all its Parts Ways and Kinds, &c.

div.head: THE Gentlewoman's Delight IN Cookery.
The Engli≈øh and French ways in dre≈ø≈øing Fle≈øh in the be≈øt, modi≈øh and advantageous manner: with their proper Sawces and Garni≈øh, &c.
A Haunch of Veni≈øon to Roa≈øt.
div.p: TAke a Haunch of Veni≈øon, indifferently fat; ≈øea≈øon it with beaten Cloves, Mace, and a little Nutmeg and Salt; and having ≈øtuck it over with Cloves or ≈ømall ≈øprigs of Ro≈øemary, lay it to the fire: ba≈øte it with Butter and Claret-wine well beaten together; and when it is enough,

Take Red-wine Vinegar, ≈øweet Butter, grated Ginger, a little Cinamon and Ro≈øe-water: boil them up to a thickne≈øs with ≈øome crumbs of Veni≈øon, and di≈øh it up, Garni≈øhing your di≈øh with ≈ølices of Lemons and Oranges.

div.head: A Fillet of Veal, to dre≈øs the be≈øt way.
div.p: Take your Fillet ≈øomewhat large, open it the fle≈øhy part with a broad pointed knife; „Äà‚óä„Äâ having Winter-≈øavory, Par≈øley, Thyme, Suet a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Spinnage ≈øhread ≈ømall, ≈øtuff it well, and clo≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the places, lay it to a gentle fire, ba≈øting it w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Butter; and when it is Roa≈øted, di≈øh it up wit ‚Ä¢ the Juyce of Oranges and ≈øweet Butter, beat ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ up with a little fine Flower; and let your Garni≈ø ‚Ä¢ be as for the former.

div.head: A Leg of Veal and Bacon, to boil the be≈øt way.
div.p: Take a good Leg of Veal and good midling Bacon, and with the Lard of the Bacon, La ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Veal; intermixing it with rows of Lemo ‚Ä¢ or Citron-peel: then tru≈øs it as round as may be, and rub it or ≈øprinkle it with Pepper an ‚Ä¢ Salt: boil it in a convenient quantity of water putting it in when the water is warm, as al≈øo your other Bacon: then take them up, ≈ølit the Bacon, and place it on each ≈øide the Veal‚ñ™ and for the Sawce, brui≈øe Sorrel, Par≈øley and Spinnage, with Sugar, Verjuice and a little Ro≈øe-water, and ≈øerve the di≈øh, garni≈øhed with pickled Barbaries, Par≈øley or Violet-leaves.

div.head: A Hare, to dre≈øs after the French Fa≈øhion.
div.p:
Take a Hare of two years old, ca≈øe her, leaving on the Ears, and lay her an hour or two in warm water; then rub her over with Pepper and Sal ‚Ä¢ ;
make then a Pudding of grated Bread, Sugar, Cinamon, chop'd Sage and White-wine, with ≈øome Suet and Butter, ≈øewing or ≈øcuring it up in the Belly of the Hare: lay her to a gentle fire, ‚Ä¢ a≈øte her with Butter, and dredge her over with fine Bread; and when enough, take out the Pudding, divide it on each ≈øide the Di≈øh, and ≈øerve her up with Verjuice, Butter and Cinamon, well mix'd or beaten together, garni≈øhing the di≈øh with blades of Mace and ≈ølices of Lemon.

div.head: A Leg of Mutton to Roa≈øt with Oy≈øters.
div.p: Take a fair Leg of Mutton, open it with a broad-pointed knife in the fle≈øhy part, ≈øundry times; then ≈øtuff in as many Oy≈øters when parboiled as you can conveniently, and ≈øtick the outward part with Cloves; and ≈øo gently roa≈øt it till enough; then ≈øerve it up with Anchovey≈øawce and ≈øtewed Oy≈øters; garni≈øhed with Flowers or Leaves: and ≈øo a ≈øhoulder of Mutton may be u≈øed.

div.head: A Pig, to Roa≈øt the mo≈øt approved way.
div.p:
Take your Pig clean ≈øcalded, opened and well dryed; which done with dryed Sage, a grated Cru≈øt, and the Gravy of Mutton, make a pudding, put it into his Belly, ≈øcuring it up, keeping him before a gentle fire, continually ba≈øting with Salt and Water, till it begin to be cri≈øp; and then let it continue till the Eyes fall out, which is a ≈øign of it's being roa≈øted; wh ‚Ä¢ reupon, take ‚Ä¢
beaten Cinamon, Sugar, Ro≈øe-water, Cu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ grated Bread, and the pure≈øt of the Gravey, „Äà‚óä„Äâ chopped Sage and Canary: make them in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Sawce, and ≈øerve up the Pig divided or c ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ with the two under Jaws and Ears; garni≈øh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ with whole Spice and Lemon Peels.

div.head: A Coney, to Boil the be≈øt way.
div.p: Take your Coney, Brace or Tru≈øs him th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ he may lye couched in your Pot or Pan; La ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ him with Bacon and Lemon Peel; and when boiled, ≈øerve him up whole, with white Bread, Sippit ‚Ä¢ Verjuice, Sugar, Butter and grated Nutmeg garni≈øhing with Par≈øley.

div.head: Veni≈øon, how to make of Kid, &c.
div.p: Take the Haunch of a fat Kid, open it in the convenient places; ≈øtuff in Salt-peter Salt, a good Quantity; then lay it in warm water till the Salt be well ≈øoaked into it: then dry it, ≈øpit it, and when Roa≈øted, ≈øerve it up with Claret, Anchovey, Pepper and a little Butter; and it will not be di≈øtingui≈øhed from Veni≈øon; the Garni≈øh mu≈øt be Spices.

div.head: To ≈øtew Lamb or Mutton, the ≈øavoure≈øt way.
div.p:
Take your Meat, ≈øea≈øon it a little with Salt and Pepper; put in convenient ≈ølices into as much Broth of the like Meat, as will cover it; ‚Ä¢ hen add a little Pepper, a blade or two of Mace, a ≈ømall quantity of Sugar, and ≈øome ≈øprigs of Ro≈øemary;
then ≈øome ≈ølices of fre≈øh Butter, and the ‚Ä¢ yce of three or four Oranges; and all being all ≈øtewed, ≈øerve the Meat up with the Broth „Äà‚óä„Äâ Sippits; Garni≈øhing with Marigolds, Par≈øley „Äà‚óä„Äâ Sugar: and in this manner is Beef ≈øtewed the „Äà‚óä„Äâ way.

div.head: To ≈øtew Veal very ≈øavourly.
div.p:
Take a Leg of Veal or any fle≈øhy part, ≈ølice thin and ≈øprinkle it over with Flower and gra
‚Ä¢ d Nutmeg; lay it in your ≈øtew pan: adding ‚Ä¢ utter and White-wine, as much as may cover „Äà‚óä„Äâ ; and then the Yolks of three or four Eggs, ‚Ä¢ ell beaten with Verjuice: la≈øtly ≈øweet Herbs, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t ≈ømall with Sugar and Currans: All which be
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ g well ≈øtewed, ≈øerve them up with Sippits; ‚Ä¢ arni≈øhed with Green.

div.head: A Fricacy of Rabits, Veal, or the like, to make the be≈øt way.
div.p: Take your Meat cut into convenient pieces, ‚Ä¢ eat and flat them with a Roaling-pin, and ≈øprinked with the Juyce of Lemon, grated Nutmeg ‚Ä¢ nd a little Flower, with a ≈ømall ≈øcattering of ‚Ä¢ weet Herbs well ≈øhread; then with the yolks ‚Ä¢ f beaten Eggs and Verjuice, cover the pieces „Äà‚óä„Äâ order, and ≈øerve them up with Sugar, Butter ‚Ä¢ nd Cinamon; garni≈øhed with green Leaves ‚Ä¢ nd in this manner, any Fricacy is made.

div.head: To Ha≈øh Mutton, Beef, Lamb, &c. the French w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
div.p:
Take your Meat half roa≈øted or boiled, ≈ølice in convenient ≈ølices, and lay it into a ≈øtew- ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ with ≈øome Butter and the broth of the Me ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ as much as will cover it; ≈øtrew thereon ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Pepper and a little Salt, ≈ølice in a Nutmeg and Shalot or two, with a little Claret-wine, if yo ‚Ä¢ think convenient or otherwi≈øe, the Juyce „Äà‚óä„Äâ a Lemon; then rub your di≈øh with a ≈øhalo ‚Ä¢ laying therein Sippits of White-bread, and ≈øer ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ up the Meat; Garni≈øhing with ≈øprinkling ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Sugar and Par≈øley.

div.head: To Fry Chickens, Pigeons, or any Fowl, &c. the be≈øt w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
div.p: Take your Fowl, being young, well pull ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and drawn; ≈ølit them and ≈øprinkle them, aft ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ you have well flatted them, by beating the ‚Ä¢ with Pepper and Salt; lay them in the pan when the Butter is already hot and melted; then ≈øprinkled ≈øhread ≈øweet herbs, and ob≈øerve to turn then in due time: and for the≈øe the Sawces in genera ‚Ä¢ are either Butter, Juyce of Lemon, and Suga ‚Ä¢ with Cinamon, or an Anchovey with a Shalot, an ‚Ä¢ ≈øweet Herbs with Pepper boiled together; an ‚Ä¢ the Garni≈øhing generally things that are green.

div.head: To Boil Chickens, Pigeons, or Wild Fowl, &c.
div.p:
Boil them a little while in water & ≈øalt till the ski ‚Ä¢ is tender; then ≈øhift them into Mutton-broth ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ adding ≈øome ≈øprigs of Ro≈øemary and other ≈øwee ‚Ä¢
Herbs; then make Sawce of Par≈øley and Sage, ‚Ä¢ oiled and ≈øhread together, with Sugar, Cina
‚Ä¢ on, Verjuice, Pepper and a ≈ømall piece of But
‚Ä¢ er; Garni≈øhing with Violet-leaves, whole Mace.

div.head: ‚Ä¢ o Stew any Tame or Wild Fowl, after the be≈øt way.
div.p: The Fowl being Pulled and Drawn; divide „Äà‚óä„Äâ into four equal quarters; ≈øprinkle them with „Äà‚óä„Äâ little Salt and Ginger, and lay them in the Pan ‚Ä¢ ell buttered: as al≈øo in the Gravy of ≈øome choice Meat: cover the Pan, till you perceive them ≈øoft; add the Juyce of one or two Oranges, ‚Ä¢ nd a ≈øprinkling of ≈øweet Herbs; after that, take them up, and place the Quarters even in the di≈øh; ‚Ä¢ he Sawce being the liquid part upon Sippits, and ‚Ä¢ he Garni≈øh Barberries and Par≈øley.

div.head: To Roa≈øt a Woodcock, Phea≈øant or Plover.
div.p: Take the Bird well pull'd and drawn: Lard them with ≈ømall ≈ølips of Bacon on the brea≈øt; and with Flower through a Drudger, rai≈øe up a Froth; then being Roa≈øted, take the Gravey, with as much Claret-wine, a little Pepper, and the Juyce of a Lemon, and boil with the Heads, Necks or Gizzards; and ≈øo ≈øerve it up with green Garni≈øh with white Bread Toa≈øts or without them.

div.head: To Roa≈øt any Hen, Pullet or Capon.
div.p:
Take Fowl, well pulled and draw'd, tru≈øs i ‚Ä¢ up and place it on your Spit, ba≈øting it moderately with Butter, and rai≈øing the froth with Flower;
then take the Gravey, ≈øome Pepper, a ≈ølice of Nutmeg and the Juyce of a Lemon; it into Sawce and ≈øerve it up; the Garni≈øh ≈ølices of Lemon, &c.

div.head: A Fore-loin of Pork, the be≈øt way to dre≈øs.
div.p: Take Pork, being laid before a gentle fire ba≈øte it fir≈øt with Salt and Water; then ≈øcorch and run it up to a cri≈øpne≈øs; which done, ma ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ your ≈øawce of green Sorrel, Sage, grated Brea ‚Ä¢ Mu≈øtard, the yolk of an Egg, Sugar, and the Leav ‚Ä¢ of Par≈øley, made ≈øomewhat thin with White-wi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and ≈øerve it up with ≈ølices of Lemon and Nutmeg, &c.

div.head: A Turkey how to Roa≈øt the French way.
div.p: Take a good Turkey, pull and draw him well place him upon your Spit, and having finger the hairs, ba≈øte him with a little White-wine, after that with Butter; then rai≈øe the Froth with Flower, and continue it till he be enough: then take the Gravey from the Fat, add to it Pepper a Shalot, and a ≈ømall quantity of Claret, putting t ‚Ä¢ them the Neck, and the Liver, well minced and ≈øo ≈øerve him up garni≈øhed with Lemon.

div.head: A Goo≈øe the French way to Roast.
div.p:
Take a fat Goo≈øe, ≈øtuff a Cru≈øt of Bread into her Belly, lay her to the fire and ba≈øte her with Salt and Water a while; then ≈øuffer her to ba≈øte her≈øelf: after ≈øhe is enough, take her up and prepa ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wce of Mu≈øtard, Sugar, white Currans and the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ p of Apples well mixed and ≈øoftned with a piece of fre≈øh Butter, and ≈øerve it up in Sawcers.

div.head: To Broyle or Toa≈øt any Fowl the be≈øt way.
div.p:
Slit your Fowl and beat it flat with a Roaling
‚Ä¢ n; then ≈øprinkle it with a little Salt and Pepper; lay it upon a Crid-iron, or hold it before ‚Ä¢ he fire with often turning till it be enough; then „Äà‚óä„Äâ your di≈øh with a Shalot. Take an Anchovey, ‚Ä¢ ome Pepper, and Claret, and make Sawce thereof, with a little piece of Butter and the Juyce of a Lemon; and ≈øerve it up with green Garni≈øh: or for want of that, ≈ølices of Lemon.

div.head: To Fry Salmon, the French way.
div.p: Take a Chine of Salmon, cut it into convenient pieces, and when the Butter is very hot in the Pan, put it in, ≈øuffering it to remain there till cri≈øp; then take the Juyce of a Lemon, an Anchovey and a piece of fre≈øh Butter, and make Sawce, ≈øerving it up with green Garni≈øh.

div.head: To Stew a Pike.
div.p:
Take a large Pike, wa≈øh the blood clean out and flat it, cover it then with Claret in the ≈øtew pan, and let it come to boiling by degrees; then add ≈øome blades of Mace and a little Cinamon, with the Juyce of a Lemon, and a good piece of
Butter with Salt enough to ≈øea≈øon it, and ≈øo d ‚Ä¢ it up with ≈øippits, ≈øprinkled with ≈øweet Herb

div.head: To Roa≈øt a Salmon the be≈øt way.
div.p: Take a Salmon, or any convenient part of h ‚Ä¢ as the Jole or Rand, ≈øea≈øoned with Nutmeg, Sa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and Pepper; and ≈øtick at the ≈øame time the o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øide with a few Cloves and ≈øome ≈ømall ≈øtips Ro≈øemary: fa≈øten it to the Spit, and at fir≈øt ba ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ it with Claret alone; then with Claret and Butter and with what falls from it, together with a Anchovey and the Juyce of a Lemon, make the Sawce and ≈øerve it up with Olives and Sampher.

div.head: To Fry Oy≈øters, an approved way.
div.p: Take the large≈øt, with the Liquor, and fry them therein, till they are ≈øomewhat tender then pour out the Liquor and put in Butter with the di≈ø≈øolved Liquor of an Anchovey ≈øome Verjuice; and ≈øo fry them till they ≈øeen cri≈øpi≈øh, then ≈øerve them up with Pepper, Butter and the Juyce of a Lemon: and in the like manner may Oy≈øter be ≈øtewed.

div.head: To Boil a Mullet, Tench, Trout or Carp.
div.p:
Take the Fi≈øh well drawed, ≈øupplying the va
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ncy of the Belly with ≈øweet Herbs; boil them „Äà‚óä„Äâ water a little ≈øea≈øoned with Salt: and when ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ough, take Butter, grated Bread, the Juyce of ‚Ä¢ range, Cinamon and Currans; make them into Sawce with the Herbs, and ≈øerve them up with ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ een Garni≈øh.

The Sawce for Eels, Flounders, Place, Roach
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , Barbles and the like, are Butter, Vinegar, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Juyce of Lemon, Anchovey, the Liquor of Pickled Oy≈øters, and the Garni≈øh green.

div.head: Salads and their Sea≈øons.
div.p:
As for Salads, they are various, according to the ≈øea≈øon; as Corn, Salads and Pickles with ‚Ä¢ ndive and French Grand Salads in Winter; and ‚Ä¢ ettice, Spinage, Pur≈ølain and Salads of Flowers, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Summer. Wherefore there being no certain Rule of this kind but the Management, according to the humour and liking of the Party, I ≈øhall ≈øubmit it to the di≈øcretion of the Ingenious Cook, ‚Ä¢ o from Salads according to the Sea≈øon or Quality of the Meats, for the be≈øt dige≈øtion; of which ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ey are prepared. And ≈øo proceed to Pa≈øtry,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ u≈øefull and nece≈ø≈øary tobe known.

div.head: Things to be ob≈øerved in Rai≈øing of Pa≈øte, &c.
div.p: In Rai≈øing of Pa≈øte, ob≈øerve that your flo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or ≈øtuff be ≈øweet and good; and that in rai≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the ≈øides, a≈øcend taper-wi≈øe; that they be kn ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed and moulded to a ≈øufficient firiene≈øs and ≈øti ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ne≈øs, not to fall or give way by jetting out „Äà‚óä„Äâ cracking, whereby the materials or fillings ma ‚Ä¢ be ≈øpoiled or lo≈øt, either by taking too much A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or running about in the Oven: Wherefore i ‚Ä¢ making them up, an e≈øpecial care mu≈øt be had that all parts are framed alike, and to be „Äà‚óä„Äâ with Liquor tolerably hot, that ≈øo the Pa≈øte th ‚Ä¢ be more firmly ≈øetled, e≈øpecially if de≈øigned „Äà‚óä„Äâ large Pyes: the fa≈øhion of which, though in th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ kind there are divers Forms may be ≈øutable t ‚Ä¢ the fancy of the maker. And having ≈øaid th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ much of the Out-≈øide, I ≈øhall proceed to ≈øpea ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of the In-≈øide, which is the mo≈øt material.

div.head: AVeni≈øon-Pa≈øty, how to make it.
div.p: Take a ≈øide of new Veni≈øon, bone it and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øon it well with Pepper and Salt: beat it wit ‚Ä¢ your Roaler into the form you de≈øign it, and clo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ up the lid or over-bearing, having fir≈øt put in „Äà‚óä„Äâ con≈øiderable quantity of Butter to prevent d ‚Ä¢ yne≈øs; and if you plea≈øe you may put in Fruit, „Äà‚óä„Äâ though it be not u≈øual.

div.head: To make an Oy≈øter-Pye.
div.p:
Your Coffin or Cru≈øt being rai≈øed, lay a lay of Butter; and then having parboiled your Oy
‚Ä¢ ters, put them in order, and over them another ‚Ä¢ aying of Butter, with ≈øome Pepper and Nutmeg; and ≈øo clo≈øe up the lid.

div.head: To make a Beef-Pa≈øty appear like Veni≈øon.
div.p: Take your Beef indifferently lean, beat it in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lces with a Roaling-pin, with ≈øome ≈øweet Herbs ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ all ≈øhread; then lay it in Pepper and Salt a light and a day; after which lay it in the coffin, and over it Butter or Marrow; then add, to keep it moi≈øt, a ≈ømall quantity of Claret, and it will be perfect, ≈øhort and red, like Veni≈øon, as has been proved.

div.head: A Goo≈øe-Pye, to make.
div.p:
Ob≈øerve to take a fat Goo≈øe, take out the Brea≈øt
‚Ä¢ one, and as many other bones as you can conveniently: flat and beat the Carka≈øs with your Roaler into the be≈øt form, then with Pepper and Salt powder it: lay then a laying of Butter at the bottom, on which place the Goo≈øe and a couple of Rabits, if you think fit; and ≈øprinkling them with Pepper, lay on more Butter, and clo≈øe ‚Ä¢ it up.

div.head: An Artichoke-Pye, to make.
div.p: Take the bottoms of Artichokes boiled, lay under them a laying of Marrow, and the like over them; then a laying of Dates, Rai≈øins an ‚Ä¢ Currans, and clo≈øe it up.

div.head: An Eel-Pye in the French fa≈øhion.
div.p: Take large ≈øilver Eels, ≈øtrip and clean≈øe them‚ñ™ cutting them in convenient lengths; Salt an ‚Ä¢ Pepper them, and ≈øhread a good quantity „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øweet Herbs: mix the Herbs with the Powder of Cinamon, and ≈øome beaten Cloves; ≈øo lay them in order upon a laying of Butter, and clo≈ø ‚Ä¢ them up.

div.head: A Neats-Tongue Pye, how to make.
div.p: Take a couple of boiled Neats-Tongues, skin them well, and mince them with Marrow or Bee≈ø≈øuet; then add of Rai≈øins and Currans, each „Äà‚óä„Äâ pound; Butter the like quantity; and Malagowine half a pint, making them up in order.

div.head: To make a Pippin, or any Apple-Tart.
div.p:
Take the Apples, pare them, cut them into four quarters, taking out the core, and lay on „Äà‚óä„Äâ laying of Sugar; place them in order; ≈ølice among≈øt
them ≈øome Quinces and candied Lemon or Orange-peel; and covering them again with Sugar, lid it up.

div.head: A Cu≈øtard, the French fa≈øhion.
div.p:
Take Cream two quarts, Saffron di≈ø≈øolved „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rained a dram, Canary half a pint, Ro≈øe-w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ alf a quarter, and Loaf-≈øugar a pound: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ them well, and put them into the coffin.

div.head: Goosberry-Tarts, Plumb-Tarts, &c. how to Fill.
div.p:
Take your Goosberrys or Plumbs green, ≈øto ‚Ä¢ them, if you may conveniently, ≈øoak them in S ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ar and Water, and after place them on a layin ‚Ä¢ of Sugar, and cover them with the like: and ≈øo you may do by any ≈øuch-like Fruits.
Broths and Jellies being wonderfull u≈øefull, I ≈øhall ≈øay ≈øomething of them.

div.head: Jelly of Calves-feet, to make.
div.p:
Take Calves-feet, without the bones, and boil ‚Ä¢ hem in a quart of White-wine, and a quart of Mutton-broth, till a third part be con≈øumed: ‚Ä¢ re≈øs out the liquid part, and ≈øea≈øon it with Cina
‚Ä¢ on and Sugar.

div.head: Cock-Broth, how to make it.
div.p:
Take a Cock of a year old, pull and draw him, beat him then with the Roaler, ≈ø ‚Ä¢ a≈øoning him with ‚Ä¢ alt and a little Pepper: put him into two gal
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ns of Mutton-broth, adding a quart of French ‚Ä¢ arley, and with beaten Nutmeg, Mace, and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eet Herbs; boil it till it will become like „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ elly, when cold.

div.head: China-Broth, to make.
div.p:
Take a gallon of Running-water, boil in it a Cock chick till it is ma≈øh; then add Rai≈øins, Li
‚Ä¢ ori≈øh, French Barley and beaten Cloves, and ≈øtrain out the liquid part for your u≈øe.

div.head: Jelly of Harts-horn, to make it.
div.p: Take the ≈øhavings of that Horn, four ounces; ≈øteep and boil it in a gallon of Water; ≈øtrain it, and add chop't Ro≈øemary, the Whites of Eggs‚ñ™ Ro≈øe-water and Sugar, and bring them up together, ≈øuffer them to ≈øtand till cold.

div.head: A Re≈øtoring Ca ‚Ä¢ dle, to make.
div.p: Take four Eggs, a dram of Saffron, half a pint of Canary, ≈øix Dates, a pint of Cream, two ounces of Loaf-≈øugar, and an ounce of Licori≈øh-powder: boil them together.

div.head: To Pickle Cucumbers, Broom-buds, A≈øh-keys, Grapes, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Plumbs, French-Beans, Barberries, Mu≈øhrooms, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Sampher, and the like: take the following Rule.
div.p:
Get a ≈øufficient quantity of good Wine-Vine
‚Ä¢ r, boil it and ≈øcum it till no more ≈øcum ari≈øe; ‚Ä¢ dding to it a handfull or two of Spani≈øh-Salt, ‚Ä¢ loves, Mace, Ginger, Cinamon, Dill and Cori
‚Ä¢ nder-≈øeed, with whole Pepper and a piece of Al
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m, and putting any of the things before-men
‚Ä¢ oned, or any other things u≈øually Pickled, and it will pre≈øerve them green and ≈øound: or for Bar
‚Ä¢ erries and Sampher, you may put Salt and Wa
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r only.

As for the decent Management of a Table, ‚Ä¢ b≈øerve that the Boiled Meats be pre≈øented fir≈øt „Äà‚óä„Äâ Cour≈øe, the Roa≈øted next, and the Baked after ‚Ä¢ hem; and la≈øtly, Pyes, Tarts, and Di≈øhes of Fruit ‚Ä¢ r Sweet-meats; ever taking notice to place the „Äà‚óä„Äâ Di≈øhes with the right end-forward, towards the upper end of the Table; The head-end of ‚Ä¢ owl, Coneys, Pigs, Fi≈øh, &c. being the right ‚Ä¢ nds; And of Joynts of Meat, the Butt or great End; and of Piggs, the picked Ends, according ‚Ä¢ o their frame or fa≈øhion.
To di≈ømember a Hern, Take off both the Legs, ‚Ä¢ nd lacing it down the Brea≈øt, rai≈øe the fle≈øh, and ‚Ä¢ ake it clean off, placing the Wings that they may ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ et.

To unbrace a Mallard, Rai≈øe up the Pinion a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Leg, not taking them off; Rai≈øe the Mer ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ thought from the Brea≈øt, and lace it down ≈ølo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wi≈øe with a Knife; the be≈øt piece being th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Wing.

To unlace a Coney, Draw the Knife do ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wards, cut off the flaps of the Belly, and take „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Shoulders, Legs, and divide the Body in fo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ parts; the be≈øt piece to pre≈øent, being held th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ next to the Tail.
To Rear a Goo≈øe, The Leg mu≈øt be opene ‚Ä¢ the Wings divided, and the Brea≈øt laced dow ‚Ä¢ the Body, after they are taken off to be divided „Äà‚óä„Äâ the be≈øt piece is the Merry-thought.

A Bu≈øtard or Turkey mu≈øt be u≈øed as th ‚Ä¢ Goo≈øe; and indeed it is a way now in u≈øe for a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ manner of Fowl, e≈øpecially Tame ones; the Me ‚Ä¢
ry-thought and Legs of which are accounted th ‚Ä¢ be≈øt piece to pre≈øent, as the Wings of all Wild fowl are on the contrary. In Fi≈øh, that part ne ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to the Head is the be≈øt: And in Fle≈øh, the middl ‚Ä¢ of the Loin, Brea≈øt, Neck, and in≈øide of the Leg or Shoulder, and in other pieces, that which i ‚Ä¢ lean and fat, as fancy or di≈øcretion may ea≈øily direct.

div.head: ‚Ä¢ he Art of Con≈øerving, Pre≈øerving, Candying and Beautifying, &c.
div.p:
TO Con≈øerve any Fruits, Herbs, Flowers or Roots, Take a like quantity of them, as of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gar; ≈øtamp them in a Mortar, and put them ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cold in a Gla≈øs or Gally-pot, keeping it from ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Air, and they will retain their ta≈øte and co
‚Ä¢ ur a twelvemonth.

Pre≈øerving is no other then to take Fruits, Flow
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, or the like, and ≈øcalding them over a gentle ‚Ä¢ re, with or without the ≈øtones, in a Pre≈øerving
‚Ä¢ an, and then the Sugar to the like quantity di≈ø
‚Ä¢ olved, put hot to them, with a ≈ømall quantity of Water or Quidany of the Fruit, and ≈øtopping them ‚Ä¢ lo≈øe up.

Candying is when the Fruits are prepared ‚Ä¢ reen, and ≈øomewhat hard, the Sugar being melt
‚Ä¢ d in the Pan to a hardne≈øs or candy, they are dip
‚Ä¢ ed into them: As for Example.

div.head: To Con≈øerve Ro≈øes.
div.p: Take off the Flower, or Red part, put them to ‚Ä¢ eep in Water or White-wine; then ≈øtamp them ‚Ä¢ o a moi≈øture, and put of the be≈øt Sugar to the weight of the Ro≈øes, making them up into a Con≈øerve for your u≈øe.

div.head: To Pre≈øerve Cherries.
div.p: Take Cherries, not too ripe, and having bo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ up your Sugar with the Quidany or Pulp of oth ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Cherries; and having made it very hot, pu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Cherries in, Stalks and all: Some there are „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øtone them, but I hold it not nece≈ø≈øary.

div.head: The Art of Candying Plumbs.
div.p: Take Plumbs but indifferently ripe, or ≈øom ‚Ä¢ what inclining to greeni≈øh; and having made Candy of Sugar, after you have ≈øoftned them „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øcalding, dip them in, or let them lay a whil ‚Ä¢ they will take the Sugar, and keep in a perfe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Candy all the year, if well dried.

div.head: An Excellent Beautifying-Wa≈øh to make the Face an ‚Ä¢ Hands fair, and take out any Spots or Deformit ‚Ä¶ in the Skin.
div.p: Take of Allom powder an ounce, Benjamine water a pint, the Flower of Ro≈øemary a handfu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Scabeous-water half a pint, Bean-flower a hand full, Copras half an ounce: heat and mix the ‚Ä¢ over a fire, and by often u≈øing you will find th ‚Ä¢ wonderous effects.
